sentences: Justin Karl Michael Broadrick (born 15 August 1969) is an English musician, singer and songwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: He is best known as a founding member of the band Godflesh, one of the first bands to combine elements of extreme metal and industrial music.
section: N/A

sentences: He was briefly in the English grindcore band Napalm Death when he was a teenager in the mid-1980s, writing and recording guitar for their debut album, Scum.
section: N/A

sentences: Broadrick has also maintained a parallel career as a producer, producing records and remixes for groups such as Pantera, Isis, Mogwai and Hydra Head labelmates Pelican.
section: N/A

sentences: Since the 1990s he has worked with Kevin Martin as Techno Animal making various genres of electronic music and hip hop.
section: N/A

sentences: Since 2012, he has been releasing hard techno music under the solo moniker JK Flesh.
section: N/A

sentences: Broadrick has set up record labels such as HeadDirt, Avalanche Recordings, Post Mortem Productions (briefly renamed Uprising Productions), Lo Fibre and Heartache.
section: N/A

== Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Broadrick was born on 15 August 1969, in the council estates of inner Birmingham.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: For the first four years of his life, Broadrick was raised by his mother Gabrielle Fern (a.k.a.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Lucy Nation) and stepfather Robert Fern (a.k.a.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Bob Allcock) in a hippie commune in Shard End.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: In the late '70s, Broadrick's mother and stepfather were members of Anti-Social, a band infamous for live shows involving blood and faecal matter, as well as for soliciting people to commit suicide via guillotine live on stage.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Anti-Social were dubbed "the world's most violent rock group" and released one single, Traffic Lights/Teacher Teacher which is now one of the rarest UK punk record releases.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: During a period of heroin addiction, Broadrick's biological father was mostly absent from the family home.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: According to Broadrick, his maternal grandmother from Germany was a "witch" who was into the occult and black magic.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: By the age of ten, Broadrick was surrounded by the punk-rock that his parents listened to.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: "There was Led Zeppelin and Black Sabbath, but it was always the stuff that wasn't so standard that grabbed me.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: I was always playing things like Lou Reed's Metal Machine Music when I was about eight!
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Stuff like Can, the weirdest parts of Pink Floyd, Hendrix", says Broadrick.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: "The first thing I probably heard out of the house, when I was about 11 years old, was Crass", says Broadrick.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Shortly after seeing them as his first concert, he recorded his first demo tape at the age of 11.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: "By the age of 12 I fell into early industrial music, stuff like Throbbing Gristle, Whitehouse".
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Broadrick began to play with his stepfather's guitar, who was then into Roxy Music and Brian Eno.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: In 1982, he started publishing tapes with his friend Andy Swan, who had a synthesizer.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: The first name they went under was Atrocity Exhibition, named after a Joy Division track (which, itself, takes its name from a book by J. G. Ballard).
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Their first recording was titled Live in the Studio and was the first catalogued release on their cassette label Post Mortem Rekordings.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Shortly after, the project was named Smear Campaign, after a Nocturnal Emissions track.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: This was the name they went under at their first live performance on 7 July 1984 in The Mermaid in Birmingham.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Promptly after the show they settled on the name Final.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Final was then inspired lyrically and musically by acts such as Throbbing Gristle and Maurizio Bianchi.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: "We were pretty heavily into the whole industrial tape culture and fanzines of the very early '80s", Broadrick says.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: The project developed to embrace the power electronics subgenre of industrial music in 1983, releasing material by them and other industrial projects on Post Mortem Rekordings (which was renamed Uprising Productions in 1985) such as Family Patrol Group, Mental Health Act, Ashenden, The Grey Wolves, Con-Dom, Death Magazine 52, Fern and Un-Kommuniti.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Final went under numerous lineup changes during its lifetime, including musicians like Philip Timms, Daniel Johnson, Paul Neville, Nicholas Bullen, Graham Robertson and Guy Pearce.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: "I had about 50 Final releases over about a year and a half", he says.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Other project names Broadrick recorded under included Last Exit, Crusade and Dead Pulp.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: Broadrick also had a short-lived progressive punk band called The Blakk Korridor with Diarmuid Dalton and Dan.
section: == Biography == | === Childhood and first recordings (1969–1983) ===

sentences: In 1984, Broadrick joined the group Fall of Because [founded by G. Christian Green and Paul Neville in 1982 initially named O.P.D. (Officially Pronounced Dead)] as a drummer and additional vocalist.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: The group recorded the Extirpate demo cassette in 1986, which contained a number of songs which were later re-worked as songs for Godflesh (including "Life Is Easy", "Mighty Trust Krusher" and "Merciless").
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: The group disbanded in 1988.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: The Life Is Easy compilation album of demo and live recordings was released in 1999.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: Broadrick met Nicholas Bullen in 1985 at the flea market where he met Andy.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: Broadrick gave Final tapes to Bullen and they recorded some material together.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: "Then I played him some of the stuff I did with guitar, which he then played to another guy in Napalm Death.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: Basically, they were impressed with what I was doing with guitar, and so I joined Napalm Death", Broadrick says.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: Soon Mick Harris (then member of a psychobilly band) joined the lineup and they shifted from metal to grindcore.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: "Nick and I left Napalm Death after we recorded the first side of Scum.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: I'd had enough of Napalm Death very, very quickly", he says.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: Lee Dorrian and Jim Whitely joined to replace Bullen and Broadrick.
section: == Biography == | === Fall of Because and Napalm Death (1984–1986) ===

sentences: Broadrick gave the first side to Earache Records founder Digby Pearson, who then contacted the new Napalm Death that had recorded the second side.

sentences: Their drummer left and Broadrick was invited to take his place.

sentences: "I was in Head of David literally six weeks, and we did a John Peel Session for Radio One.

sentences: That was the first highlight of my life", Broadrick says.
section: == Biography == | === Head of David and the forming of Godflesh (1987–1990) ===

sentences: He had been writing more brutal songs for the band, but due to artistic differences, he was kicked out in 1988.
section: == Biography == | === Head of David and the forming of Godflesh (1987–1990) ===

sentences: "When I first got exposed in '89 to the early acid house movement, I was an instant convert.
section: == Biography == | === Head of David and the forming of Godflesh (1987–1990) ===

sentences: The first time I heard early Aphex Twin, when Digeridoo first came out, I knew that this was where I wanted to go", Broadrick says.

sentences: He formed Godflesh with his friend G. C. Green.

sentences: They started with working on existing Fall of Because songs and Broadrick was influenced by the hip-hop sound at the time – artists like Public Enemy, Beastie Boys, Run-D.M.C..

sentences: Broadrick met Kevin Martin of the band GOD.

sentences: Martin had a club in Brixton and he promoted the first Godflesh show in London.
section: == Biography == | === Head of David and the forming of Godflesh (1987–1990) ===

sentences: Godflesh was met with derision on their first tour.
section: == Biography == | === Head of David and the forming of Godflesh (1987–1990) ===

sentences: However, Godflesh was well received in the United States.
section: == Biography == | === Head of David and the forming of Godflesh (1987–1990) ===

sentences: Of any music I make, it mostly goes to America", Broadrick says.
section: == Biography == | === Head of David and the forming of Godflesh (1987–1990) ===

sentences: Broadrick also revived his Final project along with his ambient guitar experiments in 1993.

sentences: In 1994, Godflesh released their album Selfless on Columbia Records and sold approximately 180,000 copies.

sentences: Broadrick joined Kevin Martin's band GOD as a guitarist for their second and final album The Anatomy of Addiction.
section: == Biography == | === Kevin Martin collaborations and electronic music (1994–1999) ===

sentences: The duo recorded the second Techno Animal album, Re-Entry, which was released as a two-disc CD through Virgin Records in 1995.
section: == Biography == | === Kevin Martin collaborations and electronic music (1994–1999) ===

sentences: Broadrick was more influenced by hip-hop and dub music when Godflesh recorded the fourth album, Songs of Love and Hate, with live drummer Bryan Mantia.

sentences: Broadrick also recorded the second Final full-length that was released on Rawkus Records.
section: == Biography == | === Kevin Martin collaborations and electronic music (1994–1999) ===

sentences: In 1997, Godflesh released the electronic remix record Love and Hate in Dub.
section: == Biography == | === Kevin Martin collaborations and electronic music (1994–1999) ===

sentences: "What Kevin and I were doing with Techno Animal then began to rub off on Godflesh, and vice versa", Broadrick says.
section: == Biography == | === Kevin Martin collaborations and electronic music (1994–1999) ===

sentences: From 1997 to 1999, Martin and Broadrick released two Techno Animal compilations, Versus Reality and Radio Hades, a split album with Porter Ricks.
section: == Biography == | === Kevin Martin collaborations and electronic music (1994–1999) ===

sentences: They also start a new project titled Curse of the Golden Vampire with Alec Empire.
section: == Biography == | === Kevin Martin collaborations and electronic music (1994–1999) ===

sentences: Broadrick also had recorded tracks as JK Flesh during this time but they were released in 2009 in the compilation album From Hell.

sentences: He turned down offers to join both Faith No More and Danzig.
section: == Biography == | === Kevin Martin collaborations and electronic music (1994–1999) ===

section: == Biography == | === Kevin Martin collaborations and electronic music (1994–1999) ===

sentences: End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003)

sentences: In 2000, Broadrick, Green and drummer Ted Parsons began work on the Godflesh album, Hymns.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: "I was already aware of Godflesh's mortality.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: Though I enjoyed a good amount of the album, I still felt a bit restricted.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: I started doing a lot of stuff during the recording of that album where I was really trying to get past the limitations of Godflesh, which were self-created".
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: After the album was released, G. C. Green left due to not wanting to tour any longer.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: Godflesh was booked for a European tour to open for Fear Factory, so Broadrick invited Paul Raven to replace Ben.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: A week into the tour Broadrick told "Raven is a fantastic bass player, but it just wasn't Benny, who I had been playing with for 13 years and was a whole part of what Godflesh was".
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: A North American tour was also planned without Broadrick's input.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: Soon after, Broadrick and his girlfriend of thirteen years broke up.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: Broadrick slipped into a mental breakdown, fled back to Birmingham and hid at a friend's house just as he was supposed to board a plane to begin the North American tour.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: Bands, equipment companies and promoters moved to recoup the lost money and Broadrick lost his house and other valuable assets in his name.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: Kevin Martin moved on to record alone as The Bug and Techno Animal was ended.
section: == Biography == | === End of Godflesh and Techno Animal (2000–2003) ===

sentences: In December, the self-titled debut LP was released.

sentences: This release featured Ted Parsons on drums, Diarmuid Dalton on bass and a guest appearance from Paul Neville.
section: == Biography == | === Jesu and Final (2004–2009) ===

sentences: The album was more melodic than his previous work.
section: == Biography == | === Jesu and Final (2004–2009) ===

sentences: "I was still making low-tuned, heavy, guttural music, at the heart of this there was something quite pretty and beautiful, just being construed in an almost ugly fashion", said Broadrick.

sentences: In November 2005 Broadrick played live as Final for the first time in 20 years and supported Jarboe.

sentences: Final's two-disc release 3 had been in making for nearly five years and was put out in 2006.

sentences: Broadrick toured Europe as Final in March 2006.

sentences: In April 2006 the Silver EP was released through Hydra Head Records.

sentences: The second full-length album, Conqueror, was released in February 2007.

sentences: Jesu toured with Sunn O))) and Isis and Broadrick played as a guest with both bands.
section: == Biography == | === Jesu and Final (2004–2009) ===

sentences: On 30 April 2007 Jesu released a 12" called Sun Down/Sun Rise.

sentences: Broadrick began to release limited runs of material on his Avalanche Recordings label, including new material by Final and a Jesu full-length compilation of electronic tracks titled Pale Sketches.

sentences: In 2008, Broadrick collaborated with former Swans vocalist Jarboe for an album titled J².
section: == Biography == | === Jesu and Final (2004–2009) ===

sentences: In May 2008, Broadrick released the first download-only final full-length, Fade Away, and the second, Afar, in October.

sentences: In 2009, Broadrick released the album Disconnected with his new band, Greymachine.
section: == Biography == | === Jesu and Final (2004–2009) ===

sentences: In January 2009, he released two new digital releases via his label Avalanche Recordings: the Krackhead album and Kitsland.

sentences: Kitsland was a recording as Council Estate Recordings with Diarmuid Dalton.

sentences: The project was influenced by Broadrick's old 1980s cassette material.

== Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013)
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===
== Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: In March 2010, Broadrick announced that he felt Jesu had strayed further away from the guitar driven music that he intended it to be and more into electronica.
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: As a resolution, although Jesu would still contain electronic elements, it would return to a guitar driven sound and a new project, titled Pale Sketcher, would allow Broadrick to explore the electronica oriented sound further without interfering with Jesu.
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: "It's more 4/4-based – shoegazy dream-pop that's almost techno, somewhat in the area of Gas and some of the early Kompakt stuff like Dettinger".
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: On 24 August 2010, he released Jesu: Pale Sketches Demixed on Ghostly International.
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: Broadrick contributed guitar soundscapes to Alan Moore's audiobook Unearthing.
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: Broadrick released the album Posthuman under the JK Flesh project name on 30 April 2012.
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: Although many of Broadrick's projects feature him performing all instrumentation anyway, the album is considered to be Broadrick's first solo album.
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: In April 2012, Valley of Fear, a new project of Broadrick, Matthew Bower and Samantha Davies, released an album of noise rock and black metal experiments on Legion Blotan Records.
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: On 11 December, a split release between JK Flesh and Prurient called Worship Is the Cleansing of the Imagination was released on Hydra Head Records.
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

sentences: On 17 June 2013, he released the free digital single Warm Sunday / Mogadon as Pale Sketcher on his new record label Heartache Records.
section: == Biography == | === Pale Sketcher and solo album (2010–2013) ===

section: == Biography == | === Signature guitar and Jesu/Sun Kil Moon collaboration (2014–present) ===

sentences: Yes!, released in October 2016.
